properties.Name: RefineryMetrics
properties.Description: Refinery metrics for the associated period.

Columns.Name: RefineryId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Refinery.

Columns.Name: PeriodStartDate
Columns.Description: The period date associated with the refinery metric.

Columns.Name: PeriodEndDate
Columns.Description: The period end associated with the refinery metric.

Columns.Name: TotalNumberRefineryEmployeesBeginningOfPeriod
Columns.Description: The total number of refinery employees at the beginning of the period.

Columns.Name: TotalNumberRefineryEmployeesHired
Columns.Description: The total number of refinery employees hired at the refinery for the period.

Columns.Name: TotalNumberRefineryEmployeesTerminated
Columns.Description: The total number of refinery employees terminated during the period.

Columns.Name: TotalNumberRefineryEmployeesRetired
Columns.Description: The total number of refinery employees that retired during the period.

Columns.Name: TotalContractorsHired
Columns.Description: The total number of contractors hired by the refinery for the period.

Columns.Name: TotalContractorsTerminated
Columns.Description: The total number of contractors terminated during the period.

Columns.Name: TotalRefineryEmployeeLaborCostsAmount
Columns.Description: the total refinery employee-related labor costs incurred by the refinery.

Columns.Name: TotalRefineryEmployeeBenefitsCostsAmount
Columns.Description: The total amount of refinery benefit-related costs incurred during the period.

Columns.Name: TotalRefineryEmployeeDependentBenefitsCostsAmount
Columns.Description: The total amount of refinery employee dependent benefit costs incurred for the period.

Columns.Name: TotalRefineryEmployeeHealthBenefitCostsAmount
Columns.Description: The total amount of refinery employee health benefit costs incurred by the refinery.

Columns.Name: TotalNumberOfRefineryEmployeeWorkDays
Columns.Description: The total number of refinery employee work days recorded for the period.

Columns.Name: TotalNumberOfRefineryEmployeeLostWorkDays
Columns.Description: The total number of lost work days by employees at the refinery for the period.

Columns.Name: TotalRefineryWorkRelatedInjures
Columns.Description: The total number of work-related injuries at the refinery for the period.

Columns.Name: TotalNumberOfRefineryDaysLostToWorkRelatedInjuries
Columns.Description: The total number of refinery work days lost to work-related injuries at the refinery for the period.

Columns.Name: TotalRefineryWorkerHoursLostToInjuries
Columns.Description: The total number of refinery worker hours lost to injuries at the refinery for the period.

Columns.Name: TotalRefineryWorkerInjuriesMedicalCostsIncurred
Columns.Description: The total amount of refinery worker injury medical costs incurred at the refinery for the period.

Columns.Name: TotalRefineryWorkerFatalities
Columns.Description: The total number of worker fatalities incurred by the refinery at the period.

Columns.Name: TotalRefineryEmployeeComplianceCostsAmount
Columns.Description: The total amount of employee compliance costs incurred by the refinery for the period.

Columns.Name: TotalRefineryWorkerLegalCompensationPaidAmount
Columns.Description: The total amount of worker legal compensation costs paid for the period.

Columns.Name: TotalRefineryEmployeeProgramCostsAmount
Columns.Description: The total amount of employee program costs incurred at the period.

Columns.Name: TotalRefineryEmployeeSubstanceAbuseIncidents
Columns.Description: The total number of employee substance abuse-related incidents at the refinery for the period.

Columns.Name: NumberRefineryIncidentsReported
Columns.Description: The total number of refinery incidents reported for the period (see INCIDENT Section).

Columns.Name: NumberRefineryInjuryIncidentsReported
Columns.Description: The number of injury-related incidents reported at the refinery for the period.

Columns.Name: NumberRefineryDeathIncidentsReported
Columns.Description: The number of death-related incidents reported at the refinery for the period.

Columns.Name: TotalRefineryExcessiveEmissionsEvents
Columns.Description: The total refinery excessive emissions events recorded at the refinery for the period.

Columns.Name: TotalRefineryEnvironmentalFinesAmount
Columns.Description: The total amount of refinery environmental fines incurred by the refinery for the period.

Columns.Name: TotalRefineryEnvironmentalComplianceCostsAmount
Columns.Description: The total amount of refinery environmental compliance costs incurred by the refinery for the period.

Columns.Name: TotalRefineryDevelopmentCostsAmount
Columns.Description: The total amount of refinery development costs expended by the refinery for the period.

Columns.Name: TotalRefineryAdministrativeCostsAmount
Columns.Description: The total refinery administrative costs incurred by the refinery for the period.

Columns.Name: TotalRefineryLaborsCostsAmount
Columns.Description: The total refinery labor costs incurred by the refinery for the period.

Columns.Name: TotalRefineryEquipmentCostsAmount
Columns.Description: The total refinery equipment costs incurred by the refinery for the period.

Columns.Name: TotalRefineryMaintenanceCostsAmount
Columns.Description: The total refinery maintenance costs incurred by the refinery for the period.

Columns.Name: TotalRefineryInventoryCostsAmount
Columns.Description: The total inventory costs incurred by the refinery for the period.

Columns.Name: TotalRefineryConstructionCostsAmount
Columns.Description: The total refinery construction costs incurred by the refinery for the period.

Columns.Name: TotalRefineryWaterUsageGallons
Columns.Description: The total water usage in gallons used by the refinery for the period.

Columns.Name: TotalRefineryWaterCostsAmount
Columns.Description: The total water-related costs incurred by the refinery for the period.

Columns.Name: TotalRefineryElectricalUsageCostsAmount
Columns.Description: The total electrical usage costs incurred by the refinery for the period.

Columns.Name: TotalRefineryElectricalUsageMw
Columns.Description: The total refinery electrical usage by the refinery for the period.

Columns.Name: TotalRefineryEnvironmentalMonitoringCostsAmount
Columns.Description: The total environment monitoring costs incurred by the refinery for the period.

Columns.Name: TotalRefineryEnvironmentalFinesCostsAmount
Columns.Description: The total environmental fines incurred by the refinery for the period.

Columns.Name: TotalRefineryTestingCostsAmount
Columns.Description: The total refinery Testing Costs Amount incurred by the refinery for the period.

Columns.Name: TotalRefineryEnergyCostsAmount
Columns.Description: The total energy usage costs incurred by the refinery for the period.

Columns.Name: NumberEmployeesToInjuriesRatio
Columns.Description:
The employees to injuries ratio for the period.

(Number of Employees/Injuries) * 100

Columns.Name: NumberEmployeesToFatalitiesRatio
Columns.Description:
The employees to fatalities ratio for the period.

(Number of Employees/fatalities) * 100

Columns.Name: NumberEmployeesToHealthBenefitsCostsRatio
Columns.Description:
Number Employees To Health Benefits Costs Ratio:

(Number Of Employees/Health Benefit Costs) * 100

Columns.Name: NumberEmployeesToDependentBenefitsCostsRatio
Columns.Description:
Number Employees To Dependent Benefits Costs Ratio:

(Number of Employees/Dependent Benefits Costs) * 100

Columns.Name: NumberEmployeesToSalaryCostsRatio
Columns.Description:
Number Employees To Salary Costs Ratio

(Number Employees/Salary Costs Ratio) * 100

Columns.Name: EmployeeToContractorRatio
Columns.Description:
Employee To Contractor Ratio:

(Number of Employee/Number of Contractors) * 100

Columns.Name: RefineryEmployeesToRefineryExpensesRatio
Columns.Description:
Refinery Employees To Refinery Expenses Ratio:

(Number Of Employees/Refinery Expense Cost) * 100

Columns.Name: EmployeeSalaryCostsToContractorCostsRatio
Columns.Description:
Employee Salary Costs To Contractor Costs Ratio

(Employee Salary Costs Amount/Contractor Costs Amount) * 100

Columns.Name: ProductionRevenueToEnvironmentalComplianceCostsRatio
Columns.Description:
Production Revenue To Environmental Compliance Costs Ratio:

(Production Revenues Amount/ Environmental Compliance Costs Amount) * 100

Columns.Name: ProductionRevenueToEmployeeSalariesCostsRatio
Columns.Description:
Production Revenue To Employee Salaries Costs Ratio:

(Production Revenue Amount/ Employee Salaries Amount) * 100

Columns.Name: ProductionRevenueToPowerUsageCostsRatio
Columns.Description:
Production Revenue To Power Usage Costs Ratio:

(Production Revenue Amount/Power Usage Costs Amount) * 100

Columns.Name: ProductionRevenueToMaintenanceCostsRatio
Columns.Description:
Production Revenue To Maintenance Costs Ratio:

(Production Revenue Amount/ Maintenance Costs Amount) * 100

Columns.Name: ProductionRevenueToDevelopmentCostsRatio
Columns.Description:
Production Revenue To Development Costs Ratio:

(Production Revenue Amount/Development Costs Amount) * 100

Columns.Name: ProductionRevenueToElectricalCostsRatio
Columns.Description:
Production Revenue To Electrical Costs Ratio:

(Production Revenue Amount/Electrical Costs Amount) * 100

Columns.Name: ProductionRevenueToWaterCostsRatio
Columns.Description:
Production Revenue To Water Costs Ratio:

(Production Revenue Amount/ Water Costs Amount) * 100

Columns.Name: ProductionRevenueToShippingCostsRatio
Columns.Description:
Production Revenue To Shipping Costs Ratio:

(Production Revenue Amount/Shipping Costs Amount) * 100

Columns.Name: ProductionCostsToElectricalCostsRatio
Columns.Description:
Production Costs To Electrical Costs Ratio:

(Production Costs Amount/ Electrical Costs Amount) * 100

Columns.Name: ProductionCostsToComplianceCostsRatio
Columns.Description:
Production Costs To Compliance Costs Ratio:

(Production Costs Amount/Compliance Costs Amount) * 100

Columns.Name: ProductionCostsToEmployeeLaborCostsRatio
Columns.Description:
Production Costs To Employee Labor Costs Ratio:

(Production Costs Amount/Employee Labor Costs Amount) * 100

Columns.Name: ProductionCostsToEmployeeBenefitCostsRatio
Columns.Description:
Production Costs To Employee Benefit Costs Ratio:

(Production Costs Amount/ Employee Benefit Costs Amount) * 100

Columns.Name: ProductionCostsToEmployeeHealthCostsRatio
Columns.Description:
Production Costs To Employee Health Costs Ratio:

(Production Costs Amount/Employee Health Costs Amount) * 100

Columns.Name: ProductionCostsToDepreciationCostsRatio
Columns.Description:
Production Costs To Depreciation Costs Ratio:

(Production Costs Amount/ Depreciation Costs Amount) * 100

Columns.Name: ProductionCostsToCatalystsCostsRatio
Columns.Description:
Production Costs To Catalysts Costs Ratio:

(Production Costs Amount/Catalysts Costs Amount) * 100

Columns.Name: ProductionCostsToAdditivesCostsRatio
Columns.Description:
Production Costs To Additives Costs Ratio:

(Production Costs Amount/ Additives Costs Amount) * 100

Columns.Name: ProductionCostsToCrudeOilCostsRatio
Columns.Description:
Production Costs To Crude Oil Costs Ratio:

(Production Costs Amount/ Crude Oil Costs Amount) * 100

Columns.Name: ProductionCostsToFeedstockCostsRatio
Columns.Description:
Production Costs To Feedstock Costs Ratio:

(Production Costs Amount/Feedstock Costs Amount) * 100

Columns.Name: CrackSpreadRatio
Columns.Description:
The crack spread is the difference in the sales price of the refined product (gasoline and fuel oil distillates) and the price of crude oil. An average refinery would follow what is known as the 3-2-1 crack spread, meaning for every three barrels of oil the refinery produces an equivalent two barrels of gasoline and one barrel of distillate fuels (diesel and heating oil).

(Product Sales Price Amount/Price of Crude Oil Amount) * 100

Columns.Name: ProductionRevenueToAssetsRatio
Columns.Description:
Production Revenue To Assets Ratio:

(Production Revenue Amount/ Assets Amount) * 100

Columns.Name: ProductionRevenueToInventoryRatio
Columns.Description:
Production Revenue To Inventory Ratio:

(Production Revenue Amount/Inventory Amount) * 100

Columns.Name: ProductionRevenuePerEmployeeRatio
Columns.Description:
Production Revenue Per Employee Ratio:

(Production Revenue Amount/Number of Employees) * 100

Columns.Name: ReturnOnAssetsRatio
Columns.Description:
Return On Assets Ratio = (Net Profit After Taxes / Tangible Total Assets Last Year) * 100

This ratio indicates how well management is in apply assets to making profits, which is another measure of the ability to earn profits.

Note that creditor equity is not differentiated from owner equity in this equation.

Since management in theory only as assets from which to make profits, this is a good measure of efficiency and ability.   If there is a large change in the number of assets, an average over time should be applied.

Variations of this ratio can focus upon different asset classes.

Columns.Name: OperatingIncomeRatio
Columns.Description:
Operating Income Ratio = (Sales - (Cost Of Sales + General & Administrative Expenses + Selling Expenses)) * 100

Income From Operations = Operating income - all expenses, which are costs of sales, G&A expenses, selling expenses etc.

This ratio is valuable for tracking and comparing operations between periods.  It shows the relationship between sales and expenses, which is an indication of the company's ability to make profits.

Columns.Name: NetIncomeRatio
Columns.Description:
(Sales + Other Income) = (All Expenses + All Taxes)

Net income is the amount remaining after adding income from all sources and deducting expenses and taxes from total sales.

Columns.Name: ProfitPerEmployeeRatio
Columns.Description:
Profit Per Employee Ratio = (Net Profit After Taxes / Number Of Employees)

This ratio compares the earnings against the number of employees that were required to achieve those earnings.   Over time, the ratio is reflective of efficiency and can be compared against other companies in the same industry.

It can be used by management for negotiating salaries, bonuses and pension/profit sharing contributions.

If the number of workers is seasonal, an average is used.

This ratio is expressed in dollars, not a percentage.

Columns.Name: ProfitGrowthRatio
Columns.Description:
Profit Growth Ratio = ((Net Profit After Taxes - Net Profit After Taxes Previous Year) / Net Profit After Taxes Previous Year) * 100

This ratio measures the ability of the business to maintain bottom line growth by turning sales in profits.

When sales growth does not correlate into increased profits there is a fundamental problem that needs to be discovered such as:

- inadequate expense controls
- reduced pricing resulting in increased sales but reduced profits.

Columns.Name: DepreciationRatio
Columns.Description:
Depreciation Ratio = (Depreciation Expense / Fixed Assets) * 100

Depreciation is related to how assets costs are spread over the life of an asset not the actual wear upon the asset.

This can be a good reference for how aggressive the accounting policies of the business are.  

The higher the ratio the more likely the company is conservative in its bookkeeping.

Columns.Name: NetIncomeToCapitalRatio
Columns.Description:
Net Income To Capital Ratio = ((Net Income - Preferred Dividends) / (Capital - Preferred Stock Par Value)) * 100

This ratio describes the return on capital in terms of unburdened or free-and-clear earnings (profit before taxes and expenses are applied).

The higher the ratio the better management is doing.

Columns.Name: InsuranceExpenseRatio
Columns.Description:
Insurance Expense Ratio = (Insurance Expense / Net Sales) * 100

This ratio measures the ability of management to control insurance expenses relative to net sales.

It is also an indicator of the responsibility business assumes for its own risks through self-insurance.

Columns.Name: ExpenseGrowthRatio
Columns.Description:
Expense Growth Ratio = ((Total Current Year Expenses - Total Previous Year Expenses) / Total Previous Year Expenses) * 100

The ability to translate sales and pricing to the bottom line, profit, is dependent upon controlling expenses.    

This ratio is a measure of expense growth over a two year period.   An effective measure of expenses is this ratio extended over a longer period of time.

Columns.Name: TotalExpenseRatio
Columns.Description:
Total Expense Ratio = (Total Expenses / Net Sales) * 100

Controlling expenses is one of the most important measures of good management.

This ratio measures total expenses as a function of net sales, which is then expressed as a percentage.

Columns.Name: UtilitiesExpenseRatio
Columns.Description:
Utilities Expense Ratio = (Utilities Expense / Net Sales) * 100

Utilities expense are those expense required to support the physical operations of the business (electricity, garbage etc.).

Columns.Name: EmployeeTurnoverRatio
Columns.Description:
Employee Turnover Ratio = (Number Employee Terminations / Number Employees) * 100

Retaining trained employees is of real value to a business.   

This ratio measures turnover of employees, which can be a result of any number of internal or economic factors.

Management must determine the cause of employee turnover and what an acceptable turnover ratio for current conditions is.

Columns.Name: IncomeFromOperationsRatio
Columns.Description:
Income From Operations Ratio = (Sales - (Costs Of Sales + Indirect Expenses)) * 100

Income from operations ('Operating Income') = sales (revenues) minus all direct and indirect expenses such as cost of sales, G&A, selling expenses, overhead etc.

Columns.Name: NewFixedAssetsRatio
Columns.Description:
Fixed Assets Ratio = (New Fixed Assets This Year / New Fixed Assets Previous Year) * 100

This ratio is a measure of the increase in the amount of new fixed assets.

Columns.Name: ExpensesToGrossProfitRatio
Columns.Description:
Expenses To Gross Profit Ratio = (Total Expenses / Gross Profit) * 100

This ratio compares total expenses to realized sales.  

If sales are different from those forecast, expenses must be adjusted in order to meet the profit levels desired.   

This ratio is particularly important when product prices must be adjusted downward.
Employee Compensation Ratio

Columns.Name: EmployeeCompensationRatio
Columns.Description:
Employee Compensation Ratio = (Total Wages Expense / Net Sales) * 100

Employee expense is the largest single expense for many companies.

Therefore, this ratio is very important to maintaining profits when expenses rise or pricing falls.

This ratio is most effective when all associated employee expenses are included such as insurance, benefits etc.

This is a measurement for identifying the efficiency of management in controlling employee expenses over an extended period of time.

Columns.Name: BudgetExpenseRatio
Columns.Description:
Budget Expense Compliance Ratio = (Total Expenses / Budgeted Total Expenses) * 100

This ratio measures the ability of management to live within their budgeted/planned expenses.

There is a problem with expense control if the ratio exceeds 100%.

Columns.Name: ReturnOnWorkingCapitalRatio
Columns.Description:
Return On Working Capital Ratio = (Net Profit After Taxes / Working Capital Last Year) * 100

This measures the return of working capital, which is that in excess of current assets (inventory, cash, notes and accounts receivable) over current liabilities.

Working capital is what management has to earn profits.   

This is a more accurate measurement of the abilities of management because it takes assets out of the equation.

Columns.Name: WorkingCapitalEfficiencyRatio
Columns.Description:
Working Capital Efficiency Ratio = ((Net Sales / (Current Assets - Current Liabilities)) * 100

Current Assets are assets that are intended to be converted to cash, used up, exchanged or sold within one accounting period, typically one year.

Current Liabilities consist of accounts payable, notes payable, accrued expenses and long-term debt due within one year.

This ratio measures how efficiently available capital, working capital, is used to generate sales.

(Production Costs Amount/Feedstock Costs Amount) * 100","isNullable":true,"scale":8,"name":"ProductionCostsToFeedstockCostsRatio"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"RefineryMetrics.cdm.json/RefineryMetrics","name":"CrackSpreadRatio"},"dataType":"decimal","dataTypeLength":18,"description":"The crack spread is the difference in the sales price of the refined product (gasoline and fuel oil distillates) and the price of crude oil. An average refinery would follow what is known as the 3-2-1 crack spread, meaning for every three barrels of oil the refinery produces an equivalent two barrels of gasoline and one barrel of distillate fuels (diesel and heating oil).

(Product Sales Price Amount/Price of Crude Oil Amount) * 100","isNullable":true,"scale":8,"name":"CrackSpreadRatio"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"RefineryMetrics.cdm.json/RefineryMetrics","name":"ProductionRevenueToAssetsRatio"},"dataType":"decimal","dataTypeLength":18,"description":"Production Revenue To Assets Ratio:

(Production Revenue Amount/ Assets Amount) * 100","isNullable":true,"scale":8,"name":"ProductionRevenueToAssetsRatio"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"RefineryMetrics.cdm.json/RefineryMetrics","name":"ProductionRevenueToInventoryRatio"},"dataType":"decimal","dataTypeLength":18,"description":"Production Revenue To Inventory Ratio:

(Production Revenue Amount/Inventory Amount) * 100","isNullable":true,"scale":8,"name":"ProductionRevenueToInventoryRatio"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"RefineryMetrics.cdm.json/RefineryMetrics","name":"ProductionRevenuePerEmployeeRatio"},"dataType":"decimal","dataTypeLength":18,"description":"Production Revenue Per Employee Ratio:

(Production Revenue Amount/Number of Employees) * 100","isNullable":true,"scale":8,"name":"ProductionRevenuePerEmployeeRatio"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"RefineryMetrics.cdm.json/RefineryMetrics","name":"ReturnOnAssetsRatio"},"dataType":"decimal","dataTypeLength":18,"description":"Return On Assets Ratio = (Net Profit After Taxes / Tangible Total Assets Last Year) * 100

This ratio indicates how well management is in apply assets to making profits, which is another measure of the ability to earn profits.

Note that creditor equity is not differentiated from owner equity in this equation.

Since management in theory only as assets from which to make profits, this is a good measure of efficiency and ability.   If there is a large change in the number of assets, an average over time should be applied.

Variations of this ratio can focus upon different asset classes.","isNullable":true,"scale":8,"name":"ReturnOnAssetsRatio"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"RefineryMetrics.cdm.json/RefineryMetrics","name":"OperatingIncomeRatio"},"dataType":"decimal","dataTypeLength":18,"description":"Operating Income Ratio = (Sales - (Cost Of Sales + General & Administrative Expenses + Selling Expenses)) * 100

Income From Operations = Operating income - all expenses, which are costs of sales, G&A expenses, selling expenses etc.

This ratio is valuable for tracking and comparing operations between periods.  It shows the relationship between sales and expenses, which is an indication of the company's ability to make profits.","isNullable":true,"scale":8,"name":"OperatingIncomeRatio"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"RefineryMetrics.cdm.json/RefineryMetrics","name":"NetIncomeRatio"},"dataType":"decimal","dataTypeLength":18,"description":"(Sales + Other Income) = (All Expenses + All Taxes)

Net income is the amount remaining after adding income from all sources and deducting expenses and taxes from total sales.","isNullable":true,"scale":8,"name":"NetIncomeRatio"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"RefineryMetrics.cdm.json/RefineryMetrics","name":"ProfitPerEmployeeRatio"},"dataType":"decimal","dataTypeLength":18,"description":"Profit Per Employee Ratio = (Net Profit After Taxes / Number Of Employees)

This ratio compares the earnings against the number of employees that were required to achieve those earnings.   Over time, the ratio is reflective of efficiency and can be compared against other companies in the same industry.

It can be used by management for negotiating salaries, bonuses and pension/profit sharing contributions.

If the number of workers is seasonal, an average is used.

This ratio is expressed in dollars, not a percentage.","isNullable":true,"scale":8,"name":"ProfitPerEmployeeRatio"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"RefineryMetrics.cdm.json/RefineryMetrics","name":"ProfitGrowthRatio"},"dataType":"decimal","dataTypeLength":18,"description":"Profit Growth Ratio = ((Net Profit After Taxes - Net Profit After Taxes Previous Year) / Net Profit After Taxes Previous Year) * 100

This ratio measures the ability of the business to maintain bottom line growth by turning sales in profits.

When sales growth does not correlate into increased profits there is a fundamental problem that needs to be discovered such as:

- inadequate expense controls
- reduced pricing resulting in increased sales but reduced profits.","isNullable":true,"scale":8,"name":"ProfitGrowthRatio"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"RefineryMetrics.cdm.json/RefineryMetrics","name":"DepreciationRatio"},"dataType":"decimal","dataTypeLength":18,"description":"Depreciation Ratio = (Depreciation Expense / Fixed Assets) * 100

Depreciation is related to how assets costs are spread over the life of an asset not the actual wear upon the asset.

This can be a good reference for how aggressive the accounting policies of the business are.  

The higher the ratio the more likely the company is conservative in its bookkeeping.","isNullable":true,"scale":8,"name":"DepreciationRatio"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"RefineryMetrics.cdm.json/RefineryMetrics","name":"NetIncomeToCapitalRatio"},"dataType":"decimal","dataTypeLength":18,"description":"Net Income To Capital Ratio = ((Net Income - Preferred Dividends) / (Capital - Preferred Stock Par Value)) * 100

This ratio describes the return on capital in terms of unburdened or free-and-clear earnings (profit before taxes and expenses are applied).

The higher the ratio the better management is doing.","isNullable":true,"scale":8,"name":"NetIncomeToCapitalRatio"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"RefineryMetrics.cdm.json/RefineryMetrics","name":"InsuranceExpenseRatio"},"dataType":"decimal","dataTypeLength":18,"description":"Insurance Expense Ratio = (Insurance Expense / Net Sales) * 100

This ratio measures the ability of management to control insurance expenses relative to net sales.

It is also an indicator of the responsibility business assumes for its own risks through self-insurance.","isNullable":true,"scale":8,"name":"InsuranceExpenseRatio"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"RefineryMetrics.cdm.json/RefineryMetrics","name":"ExpenseGrowthRatio"},"dataType":"decimal","dataTypeLength":18,"description":"Expense Growth Ratio = ((Total Current Year Expenses - Total Previous Year Expenses) / Total Previous Year Expenses) * 100

The ability to translate sales and pricing to the bottom line, profit, is dependent upon controlling expenses.    

This ratio is a measure of expense growth over a two year period.   An effective measure of expenses is this ratio extended over a longer period of time.","isNullable":true,"scale":8,"name":"ExpenseGrowthRatio"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"RefineryMetrics.cdm.json/RefineryMetrics","name":"TotalExpenseRatio"},"dataType":"decimal","dataTypeLength":18,"description":"Total Expense Ratio = (Total Expenses / Net Sales) * 100

Controlling expenses is one of the most important measures of good management.

This ratio measures total expenses as a function of net sales, which is then expressed as a percentage.","isNullable":true,"scale":8,"name":"TotalExpenseRatio"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"RefineryMetrics.cdm.json/RefineryMetrics","name":"UtilitiesExpenseRatio"},"dataType":"decimal","dataTypeLength":18,"description":"Utilities Expense Ratio = (Utilities Expense / Net Sales) * 100

Utilities expense are those expense required to support the physical operations of the business (electricity, garbage etc.).","isNullable":true,"scale":8,"name":"UtilitiesExpenseRatio"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"RefineryMetrics.cdm.json/RefineryMetrics","name":"EmployeeTurnoverRatio"},"dataType":"decimal","dataTypeLength":18,"description":"Employee Turnover Ratio = (Number Employee Terminations / Number Employees) * 100

Retaining trained employees is of real value to a business.   

This ratio measures turnover of employees, which can be a result of any number of internal or economic factors.

Management must determine the cause of employee turnover and what an acceptable turnover ratio for current conditions is.","isNullable":true,"scale":8,"name":"EmployeeTurnoverRatio"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"RefineryMetrics.cdm.json/RefineryMetrics","name":"IncomeFromOperationsRatio"},"dataType":"decimal","dataTypeLength":18,"description":"Income From Operations Ratio = (Sales - (Costs Of Sales + Indirect Expenses)) * 100

Income from operations ('Operating Income') = sales (revenues) minus all direct and indirect expenses such as cost of sales, G&A, selling expenses, overhead etc.","isNullable":true,"scale":8,"name":"IncomeFromOperationsRatio"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"RefineryMetrics.cdm.json/RefineryMetrics","name":"NewFixedAssetsRatio"},"dataType":"decimal","dataTypeLength":18,"description":"Fixed Assets Ratio = (New Fixed Assets This Year / New Fixed Assets Previous Year) * 100

This ratio is a measure of the increase in the amount of new fixed assets.","isNullable":true,"scale":8,"name":"NewFixedAssetsRatio"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"RefineryMetrics.cdm.json/RefineryMetrics","name":"ExpensesToGrossProfitRatio"},"dataType":"decimal","dataTypeLength":18,"description":"Expenses To Gross Profit Ratio = (Total Expenses / Gross Profit) * 100

This ratio compares total expenses to realized sales.  

If sales are different from those forecast, expenses must be adjusted in order to meet the profit levels desired.   

This ratio is particularly important when product prices must be adjusted downward.
Employee Compensation Ratio","isNullable":true,"scale":8,"name":"ExpensesToGrossProfitRatio"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"RefineryMetrics.cdm.json/RefineryMetrics","name":"EmployeeCompensationRatio"},"dataType":"decimal","dataTypeLength":18,"description":"Employee Compensation Ratio = (Total Wages Expense / Net Sales) * 100

Employee expense is the largest single expense for many companies.

Therefore, this ratio is very important to maintaining profits when expenses rise or pricing falls.

This ratio is most effective when all associated employee expenses are included such as insurance, benefits etc.

This is a measurement for identifying the efficiency of management in controlling employee expenses over an extended period of time.","isNullable":true,"scale":8,"name":"EmployeeCompensationRatio"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"RefineryMetrics.cdm.json/RefineryMetrics","name":"BudgetExpenseRatio"},"dataType":"decimal","dataTypeLength":18,"description":"Budget Expense Compliance Ratio = (Total Expenses / Budgeted Total Expenses) * 100

This ratio measures the ability of management to live within their budgeted/planned expenses.

There is a problem with expense control if the ratio exceeds 100%.","isNullable":true,"scale":8,"name":"BudgetExpenseRatio"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"RefineryMetrics.cdm.json/RefineryMetrics","name":"ReturnOnWorkingCapitalRatio"},"dataType":"decimal","dataTypeLength":18,"description":"Return On Working Capital Ratio = (Net Profit After Taxes / Working Capital Last Year) * 100

This measures the return of working capital, which is that in excess of current assets (inventory, cash, notes and accounts receivable) over current liabilities.

Working capital is what management has to earn profits.   

This is a more accurate measurement of the abilities of management because it takes assets out of the equation.","isNullable":true,"scale":8,"name":"ReturnOnWorkingCapitalRatio"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"RefineryMetrics.cdm.json/RefineryMetrics","name":"WorkingCapitalEfficiencyRatio"},"dataType":"decimal","dataTypeLength":18,"description":"Working Capital Efficiency Ratio = ((Net Sales / (Current Assets - Current Liabilities)) * 100

Current Assets are assets that are intended to be converted to cash, used up, exchanged or sold within one accounting period, typically one year.

Current Liabilities consist of accounts payable, notes payable, accrued expenses and long-term debt due within one year.

This ratio measures how efficiently available capital, working capital, is used to generate sales.","isNullable":true,"scale":8,"name":"WorkingCapitalEfficiencyRatio"}]}}}
Properties.Description: Refinery metrics for the associated period.
